Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Summary
This award supports theoretical research and education at the interface between physics, materials science and engineering. Though 3D printing has become inexpensive enough for prototyping, it has numerous drawbacks as a manufacturing technique, including speed and configurability. Yet, there are a number of materials that can be made to controllably grow from a flat sheet to a targeted three-dimensional structure. The PI's group will develop understanding and design tools to optimally pattern a thin sheet to fold and buckle into a targeted shape and study how an elastic sheet wrinkles to accommodate curvature. Together, these projects unveil the relationship between elasticity and geometry, and enable the development of tools to improve manufacturing of structured materials.
The work will have an impact on the design of structured materials by introducing new analytical techniques for the prediction of three-dimensional structures, enabling applications in advanced manufacturing and soft robotics. The award contributes to the education of graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary field and through substantial interactions with experimental research groups. It also supports the PI's efforts at outreach to the general public.

Technical Summary
This award supports studies of three-dimensional structure formation in two-dimensional elastic sheets. Recent progress in the fabrication of polymeric structures have allowed the development of active materials that can, through spatially non-uniform growth, buckle into targeted three-dimensional structures.
This research project has two goals. First, it will extend the mathematical foundation laid down to understand the buckling of thin films due to non-uniform growth to allow the design of optimal pattern of growth. Second, it will explore the related problem of how a sheet can conform to a curved surface by wrinkling. The results of this second project will then be used to explore what happens when a growing sheet cannot alleviate all of its in-plane stresses by buckling smoothly.
The work will have an impact on the design of structured materials by introducing new analytical techniques for the prediction of three-dimensional structures, enabling applications in advanced manufacturing and soft robotics. The award contributes to the education of graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary field and through substantial interactions with experiments. It also supports the PI's efforts at outreach to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
4D printing is a manufacturing technique whereby a flat sheet of material undergoes a non-uniform pattern of local growth to buckle into a targetted 3D structure. The idea works because of a concept called geometric frustration. In a material exhibiting geometric frustration, the local geometry it wants to adopt is not compatible with its global shape. In the case of growing sheets, different patterns of growth become incompatible with the sheet remaining flat, and the resulting sheet buckled into three dimensions to alleviate this frustration.

A primary obstacle to realizing this commercially is that many material systems can undergo only a limited range of growth. Our project developed an algorithm that takes an initial 3D shape and the range of growth that can be obtained experimentally as input, and produces a flat shape and pattern of growth required to reproduce the shape as closely as we can. The algorithm has also resulted in the development of code that is available by request to produce the desired swelling patterns.

In tandem with this theoretical work, we used our algorithm to generate growthj patterns for sheets that contain both spatial patterns that vary not only across the area of an initially flat shape, but also through the thickness. This allows us to control more aspects of the shape. In collaboration with the group of Ryan Hayward, who developed an experimental technique control the swelling of a gel according to our theoretical "program", we were able to demonstrate this technique experimentally.

We also explored geometric frustration in the case of buckles of twisted fibers. These kinds of fibrous materials are common at many scales, all the way from bundles of DNA and other proteins in cells to the twisted steel cables that hold up our bridges. What we studied, in particular, was the fact that twisting the fibers is geometrically incompatible with the fibers maintaning a uniform separation, at least sometimes. We were able to quantify this and develop new ways of estimating the configuration of fibers in twisted bundles.

This project trained two graduate students in physics to use modern theoretical and computational techniques to solve real-world relevant materials problems and collaborate closely with experimentalists. It also funded outreach efforts to inspire interest among middle schoolers in fundamental problems from the physics of materials. The software and algorithms we have produced have been published in peer-reviewed journals and are available by request.
